Graphical abstract TiO2 nanotubes (TNTs) have been extensively applied in many fields owing to their excellent porous structure and surface properties. Herein, a series of CuO-ZnO-CeO2/TNTs catalysts are synthesized through a deposition-precipitation method. The effects of TNTs content and support morphology on the catalyst physicochemical properties and catalytic performance are investigated. The incorporation of TNTs support into CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalysts not only promotes CuO reducibility and improves the metallic Cu dispersion and specific surface area, but also enhances CO2 adsorption and increases the proportion of basic sites γ, thereby resulting in high CO2 conversion and CH3OH selectivity. It is also shown that CO2 conversion is positively correlated with the Cu specific surface area and that CH3OH selectivity is related to the proportion of basic sites γ. Due to the excellent reducibility, high metallic Cu surface area, superior CO2 adsorption and large proportion of basic sites γ, CuO-ZnO-CeO2/10 wt.% TNTs gives excellent catalytic performance and possesses a great potential as catalyst for methanol synthesis. Keywords TiO2 nanotubes Deposition-precipitation method CO2 hydrogenation Methanol synthesis Strong basic site 1 Introduction The increasing demands of fossil energy and the growing concentrations of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) have accelerated the imminent crisis of environment and energy, requiring exploitation of clean and sustainable energy sources as alternative options [1–5]. Industrial CO2 capture and storage (CCS) process and chemical transformation have been regarded as effective methods for utilization of a great amount of CO2 and production of renewable energy [6]. Especially, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol (CH3OH) has become a potentially significant process, because methanol is not only employed as an admixture for fuels and raw material for fuel cells [7], but also can be used as a key chemical precursor for synthesis of high molecular weight hydrocarbons and alternative fuels [8,9]. Nevertheless, direct hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol still exists underlying obstacles to overcome, including high thermodynamic stability and poor CO2 reactivity which lead to undesirable CO2 conversion [10,11]. In addition, CO produced from reverse water-gas shift (rWGS) reaction is difficult to avoid [12]. Thus, the exploitation of highly effective catalysts to enhance CO2 hydrogenation performance is still required. Cu-based particularly Cu-ZnO based catalysts have been extensively reported for methanol formation from CO2 hydrogenation [13–17]. The incorporation of zinc oxide into metallic Cu catalysts enhances the dispersion of metallic copper nanoparticles. Moreover, the Cu/ZnO interface can be formed owing to the imitate interaction between ZnO and Cu, which acts as an active site for hydrogen spillover and CO2 adsorption [18,19]. While Cu-ZnO based catalysts have also been reported for methanol formation, these catalysts are not widespread since the metals have low active surface area and the sintering of metal phases easily occurs. Therefore, various research efforts have been employed for improving metal surface area and thermal resistance of Cu-based catalysts by modifying the catalyst components and structures. Due to the favorable proprieties of ZrO2 and CeO2, these two metal oxides have been used to modify Cu-based catalysts to get its superior properties. Arena et al. [20] synthesized Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst by reverse co-precipitation method and utilized for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. The resulting catalyst showed an enhanced activity compared with the referenced Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. Dong et al. [21] prepared Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst using NaBH4 as reductant. The NaBH4 content had an obvious influence on the catalyst properties, and thus greatly affected the CO2 hydrogenation performance. The highest selectivity of methanol (66.8%) was got with B/Cu = 5 at 503 K. Witoon et al. [22] discovered that the decreased mass ratio of Cu/Zn facilitated the formation of smaller CuO crystal size, higher metal oxides porosity and dispersion, resulting in an increase in the number of catalytic sites, and thus enhanced the catalytic performance at lower reaction temperature. Liu et al. [23] confirmed that the addition of ZrO2 into Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst beneficial to obtain a large number of defects, corners, edges and oxygen vacancies, which favored to improve the reducibility of CuO and led to a more superior performance for methanol formation. Ouyang et al. [24] reported the morphology effect of nanostructured ceria in the Cu/CeO2 catalyst on catalytic performance and discovered that the CeO2 nanorod supported-Cu catalyst showed more excellent catalytic performance than CeO2 nanocube and nanoparticle supported-Cu catalysts. Wang et al. [25] found that the incorporation of ceria into Cu/γ-Al2O3 dramatically improved the catalytic performance, which was attributed to the synergistic effect of CuO species and the surface oxygen vacancies of ceria. Moreover, the introduction of supports into the Cu-based catalysts not only optimized the catalyst physicochemical properties but also enhanced their reactivity. Wu et al. [26] reported that introducing reduced graphene oxide (rGO) into CuO-ZnO-ZrO2-Al2O3 enhanced the adsorption capacity of H2 and CO2. Sun et al. [27] observed much more active sites in pyridinic nitrogen dominant CNTs supported catalyst (CZ/CNT-N) than those in pyrrolic nitrogen dominant CNTs supported catalyst (CZ/CNT-NH2). Thus, the highest CH3OH yield of 8.64% and space-time yield of 102.21 mg gcat −1 h−1 can be obtained. In addition to these non-metal carriers, metal oxides SiO2 and TiO2 were also used as additives for Cu-based catalysts because they have better thermal stability and higher surface energy [28–30]. Phongamwong et al. [28] reported that the incorporation of SiO2 improved the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation performance and stability of CuO-ZnO-ZrO2 catalyst. Zhang et al. [30] investigated SiO2, TiO2 or TiO2-SiO2 support for ternary CuO-ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst and found that all the supports not only improved the CuO dispersion but also facilitated the adsorption/activation of H2 on the catalysts. Jia et al. [31] recognized that the incorporation of SiO2 into CuO-ZnO-ZrO2 significantly promoted the dispersion and reducibility of the catalyst. The CuO-ZnO-ZrO2 catalyst with 4 wt.% SiO2 showed the maximum CO2 conversion of ˜22.8% and CH3OH selectivity of ˜45%. Arakawa et al. [32] pointed out that incorporating TiO2 support into the CuO-ZnO composite catalyst was beneficial for accelerating the quick rehabilitation of copper phase to metallic state from somewhat oxidized state due to the excellent hydrogen donating ability of TiO2. Titanium dioxide nanotubes (TNTs) have been attracting wide attention since they not only combine the features of traditional 0-dimensional (0-D) titanium dioxide nanoparticles including low-cost, chemically stable and nontoxic but also are with unique properties such as large specific surface area, high aspect ratio and excellent electron/proton conductivity [33,34]. All these advantages make TNTs extensively applied in many fields, for example, gas sensors, wastewater purification, dye-sensitized solar cells, organic pollutants degradation and photocatalytic water splitting [35–38]. As far as we know, there has been no report about TiO2 nanotubes supported catalysts for CH3OH formation. Therefore, we put forward the synthesis of TiO2 nanotubes supported CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalysts with a good try to exploit a remarkably effective catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. The composite catalysts were prepared through a deposition-precipitation method. For comparison, the P25 supported CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalyst was also synthesized using the identical method. All catalysts were characterized using different techniques to determine the influences of TNTs content and support morphology on the catalyst structures and physicochemical properties. We established the correlation between physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of the catalysts. Moreover, a bifunctional mechanism for CH3OH formation from CO2 hydrogenation was also proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were analytical-reagent grade and obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. China. They were used as-received without further purification. TiO2 nanotubes (TNTs) were firstly prepared through a hydrothermal method using P25 (commercial TiO2 powder, Degussa, Germany) as raw material. Under vigorous stirring and ultrasound irradiation, 0.5 g of P25 was added into 60 mL of 10 mol/L NaOH aqueous solution. Subsequently, the resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-coated stainless autoclave and maintained at 180 °C for 48 h. The as-obtained product was filtered and completely washed with distilled water. After drying 6 h at 80 °C, the power sample was redispersed into 500 mL of 0.1 mol/L HCl aqueous solution for 60 h at room temperature. Afterwards, the resulted product was thoroughly washed with distilled water until upper solution pH = 7, dried at 80 °C overnight before calcined in air at 600 °C for 2 h. CuO-ZnO-CeO2/TNTs composite catalysts with different TNTs contents were prepared through a deposition-precipitation method. Taking the CuO-ZnO-CeO2/10 wt.% TNT catalyst for example, 0.199 g of TNTs was dispersed into 50 mL of distilled water by ultrasound irradiation for 15 min to obtain a white suspension solution. Then, under vigorous stirring, a metal salts solution of 0.6 mol/L Cu(NO3)2, 0.3 mol/L Zn(NO3)2 and 0.1 mol/L Ce(NO3)3, and an aqueous solution of 1.0 mol/L Na2CO3 were added simultaneously and slowly into the above suspension solution at 70 °C. The precipitation pH was maintained constant at about 9.0. The obtained mixture was aged for 3 h at ambient condition, followed by filtration, washing, drying at 80 °C for 12 h, and calcined at 350 °C in air for 5 h. Because the collected samples were synthesized in the identical molar ratio (6:3:1) of Cu, Zn and Ce, they were denoted as CZC, CZC/1TNTs, CZC/5TNTs, CZC/10TNTs and CZC/15TNTs, respectively. To further study the impact of support morphology on the catalyst properties and catalytic CO2 hydrogenation performance, the CuO-ZnO-CeO2/10 wt.% P25 composite catalyst was also prepared using the identical method, and the obtained sample was named as CZC/10P25. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The elemental analysis of the calcined catalyst was performed on a Varian 720-ES inductively-coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of both calcined and reduced catalysts were recorded with a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα irradiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The crystal phases were identified using the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). The size of crystal was calculated by Scherrer equation, D hkl = kλ/(βcosθ), where D hkl is the size of crystal in the direction perpendicular to the plane [hkl], k is the Scherrer constant which is regarded as usually 0.89, and λ is the incident X-ray wavelength, θ is the Bragg diffraction angle, and β is the half-height peak width of the diffraction peak. Nitrogen physisorption was conducted at −196 °C on a QuantaTech Auto-sorb-iQA3200-4 analyzer. The calcined catalyst was degassed under high vacuum at 300 °C for 5 h prior to the measurement. The morphology and structure of the calcined catalysts were carried out using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements on a JEM-2100 F field emission electron microscope. The Cu dispersion (D Cu) and Cu surface area (S Cu) were measured by dissociative N2O adsorption on a Micrometric ChemiSorb 2750 instrument. A 0.1 g catalyst was purged in He at room temperature for 0.5 h and reduced with 10 vol.% H2/He (50 mL/min) at 350 °C for 2 h. The reduced catalyst was swept in He for 1 h and cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, the reduced catalyst was exposed to N2O for 1 h to ensure complete oxidation of metallic copper, followed by flushing in He for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed N2O. Finally, the catalyst was reduced again in 10 vol.% H2/He at 350 °C, and the amount of consumed H2 was labeled as n H2. The D Cu and S Cu were calculated by the following equations: D Cu (%) = [(2n H2×M Cu)/(W×XCu)]×100 and S Cu (m2/g) = (2n H2×N a)/(W×1.46 × 1019), where n H2 is the molar number of consumed H2, M Cu is the molecular weight of atomic Cu (63.456 g·mol−1), W is the catalyst weight, XCu is the stoichiometric composition of Cu (wt.%), N a is the Avogadro’s constant (6.02 × 1023 atoms·mol−1), and 1.46 × 1019 is copper surface density [39]. The reducibility of the calcined catalysts was studied by H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurement with a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-C chemisorption instrument. The catalyst was purified with He at room temperature for 0.5 h, Subsequently, H2-TPR measurement was begun with heating rate of 10 °C/min under a 10 vol.% H2/He gas mixture (50 mL/min) until the temperature of 700 °C was reached. The CO2 adsorption capacity was carried out by CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) on the Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-C chemisorption instrument. A 0.1 g catalyst was placed in a quartz tube and purified with He at room temperature for 0.5 h and reduced with 10 vol.% H2/He (50 mL/min) at 350 °C for 2 h, respectively. The reduced catalyst was swept in He for 1 h and cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, the sample was exposed to CO2 for 1 h to adsorb CO2, followed by purging with He for 1 h to remove physisorbed CO2. The TPD profile was recorded in He flow from 50 to 750 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. 2.3 Catalyst test Catalytic test was isothermally carried out at high pressure in a stainless steel tubular fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm. Firstly, 0.2 g of a calcined catalyst (20–40 mesh) was mixed with 0.5 g of inert silica sand (20–40 mesh), and then loaded into the reactor. A thermocouple was inserted near the bottom of the catalyst bed to measure the reaction temperature. Before the catalytic measurement, the catalyst was reduced in-situ with flowing H2 (50 mL·min−1) at 350 °C for 2 h. After reduction, the catalyst bed was cooled to 200 °C and then purged with a mixed reactant gas (CO2: H2: N2 = 1: 3: 1, molar ratio). The total reaction pressure was raised and kept at 3.0 MPa, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was kept at 7500 mL·gcat −1 h−1. The reaction temperature was controlled in turn at 220, 240, 260, 280 and 300 °C. A programmable heat controller was installed to maintain a stable temperature for the effluent gaseous products to avoid condensation. The outlet gases were periodically sampled and analyzed by an online gas chromatography (INESA, GC126, China) equipped with a two-column system connected to FID (CH3OH, CH4) and TCD (N2, CO, CO2, CH4), respectively. CO2 conversion (X CO2), CH3OH selectivity (S CH3OH), CH3OH space time yield (STY CH3OH) and turnover frequency (TOF CH3OH) were calculated, respectively, as follows: (1) X C O 2 % = C O 2 − C O 2 C O 2 in × 100 (2) S C H 3 OH % = C H 3 OH out C O 2 in − C O 2 out × 100 (3) S T Y C H 3 OH mmo l C H 3 OH ⋅ h − 1 ⋅ g cat -1 = F C O 2 , in ⋅ X C O 2 ⋅ S C H 3 OH (4) T O F C H 3 OH s − 1 = S T Y C H 3 OH ⋅ N a S C u ⋅ 1.46.10 19 ⋅ 3600 where [CO2]in and [CO2]out are the amount of CO2 at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, [CH3OH]out is the amount of CH3OH at the outlet of the reactor, F CO2, in is the molar flow rate, and W cat is the used catalyst weight. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and crystal properties of catalysts The support contents and metal compositions were quantified using ICP-AES, and the corresponding results are listed in Table 1 . The measured metal compositions and support contents of all catalysts are in close agreement with the theoretical values, suggesting that the deposition-precipitation method is an ideal method to synthesize supported catalysts with high loading of metal oxides. The influence of TNTs or P25 support incorporation into the CuO-ZnO-CeO2 composites on the crystal phases of the obtained catalysts after calcination and reduction was studied by XRD measurement, and the diffraction patterns are displayed in Fig. 1 . It can be seen from Fig. 1a that the characteristic peaks of CZC at 2θ = 32.5°, 35.6°, 38.8°, 48.7°, 58.3°, 61.8° and 66.5° are attributed to the (110), (002), (111), (02), (020), (113) and (11) planes of tenorite phase (JCPDS 48–1548), respectively. All those peaks appearing at 31.8°, 34.4°, 36.2°, 47.6°, 56.6°, 62.9° and 68.1°correspond to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103) and (112) planes of hexagonal wurtzite ZnO (JCPDS 36–1451), respectively. The remaining diffraction peaks at 28.6°, 47.6° and 56.6° are indexed to the (111), (220) and (311) planes of cubic CeO2 (JCPDS 34-0394), respectively. Furthermore, the crystallite structure of pure TNTs has also been characterized and phases of the phases of TiO2 are clearly identified. The XRD patterns of all supported catalysts exhibit the identical characteristic peaks to those of the un-supported catalyst (CZC), suggesting that adding TNTs or P25 to the CuO-ZnO-CeO2 system has not change the crystal phases of the supported composites. As shown in Fig. 1a, with the increase of TNTs content, the characteristic peak at 2θ of 25.3° attributed to (101) plane of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS 21–1272) appears gradually. CuO-ZnO-CeO2/15TNTs presents the strongest diffraction peak due to the highest TNTs content. However, incorporating TNTs or P25 leads to a decrease in peak intensity and increase in peak width of the CuO characteristic peaks, implying that CuO dispersion increases and crystallization degree decreases significantly. This phenomenon might be ascribed to larger BET specific surface area of the supported catalysts than that of CZC, which will be discussed later. After reduction at 350 °C (Fig. 1b), CuO phase disappears and the diffraction peaks (43.3°, 50.3° and 73.8°) of metallic Cu phase are disclosed in all catalysts, suggesting that CuO is completely reduced. Specially, CZC shows the highest diffraction peaks of metallic Cu, which shows that small metallic Cu particles agglomerate together to form larger Cu clusters during reduction treatment. In Table 1, Cu0 crystal size of all catalysts is calculated and listed. It can be seen that crystal size of Cu0 crystallites decreases with the addition of TNTs or P25, suggesting that the presence of support inhibits the growth of Cu0 crystallites and enhances the dispersion of Cu0 metal particles. Furthermore, compared with the calcined catalysts, the crystalline phases of ZnO and CeO2 in all the reduced catalysts have no obvious change. The TEM characterization was directly used to observe the shape and microstructure of three selected samples including pure TNTs, CZC/10TNTs and CZC/10P25, and the corresponding images are presented in Fig. 2 . Fig. 2a exhibits that pure TNTs exhibit the 1-dimension tubular morphology with the outer diameters of 60–80 nm and lengths of several hundred nanometers, and no TiO2 nanoparticles exist after hydrothermal treatment. In Fig. 2b, metal oxides present particle-like shape with size of about 20–30 nm, which are uniformly dispersed onto the surface of the TNTs, Furthermore, after loading of metal oxides, the nanotube structure, size and morphology are well remained. However, as clearly shown in Fig. 2c, P25 support stacks obviously and a large number of metal particles aggregate together to generate bigger clusters in the CZC/10P25 catalyst. The HRTEM image of CZC/10TNTs is also displayed in Fig. 2d. The lattice fringes with d-spacing of 0.32 and 0.35 nm, corresponding to the planes (111) of cubic CeO2 and (111) of anatase TiO2, respectively [40–42]. In addition, the lattice fringe with d-spacing of 0.25 nm coincides with the (002) plane of CuO in CZC/10TNTs (inset, Fig. 2b). To further identify the distribution of metal oxide phases and interaction between the Cu and Zn and Ce phases in CZC/10TNTs, EDX elemental mapping of the calcined CZC/10TNTs catalyst was carried out and the images are displayed in Fig. S1. It is clear that a large proportion of metal oxides finely disperse on the surface of TNTs. In addition, all metal phases are in close contact with each other, indicating the existence an intimate interaction between the Cu and Zn and Ce phases. As mentioned above, this TNTs-supported structure shows that TiO2 nanotubes are closely covered by metal particles, providing a high contact interface area, which is more beneficial for enhancing metal dispersion and CO2 hydrogenation activity. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms as well as pore diameter distribution curves of all calcined catalysts are presented in Fig. S2. The responding results are summarized in Table 1. Fig. S2a presents the typical BDDT Type IV isotherms with hysteresis loops of type H4 which has a sharp rise at relative pressure of 0.9. This indicates a mesoporous structure for the as-prepared catalysts [43]. It can be found that with the addition of TNTs in the CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalysts, the specific BET surface area and pore volume (80.4 m2/g and 0.340 cm3/g of CZC) increase at first, reach their maximum values (131.2 m2/g and 0.502 cm3/g) at a TNTs content of 10 wt.%, and then decrease with the increase of TNTs content, which is attributed to that higher TNTs content result in inhomogeneous microstructure and segregation of the catalyst particles [28]. Nevertheless, the specific BET surface area and pore volume of CZC/10P25 are both lower than those of CZC/10TNTs, suggesting that TNTs support possesses large specific surface area and excellent porous structure. The order of these two parameters is as follows: CZC < CZC/1TNTs < CZC/10P25 < CZC/15TNTs < CZC/5TNTs < CZC/10TNTs. However, there is a remarkable difference in pore diameter distribution between the CZC sample and the supported samples (Fig. S2b). For CZC, only one pore diameter distribution is detected at about 2–5 nm, whereas, two broad pore diameter distribution, for the other supported samples, are centered at around 2–5 and 10–30 nm, respectively. These results indicate that pore diameter distribution is significantly affected with the addition of TNTs or P25. In addition, compared with the TNTs-supported catalysts, CZC/10P25 presents a similar pore diameter distribution in the small pore range (located at about 2–5 nm), while in larger pore range, the pore diameter distribution shifts towards a smaller size (appear at 10–20 nm). This illustrates that the pores in TNTs are bigger than that in P25. The Cu surface area and Cu dispersion derived from dissociative N2O adsorption of the reduced catalysts are listed in Table 1. The D Cu and S Cu of CZC are 6.3% and 20.0 m2/g, respectively, which are both lower than those of the TNTs or P25 supported catalysts. It can also be found that the D Cu and S Cu increase gradually when the TNTs content increases from 1 to 10 wt.%, and the maximum values of 10.2% and 29.6 m2/g at a TNTs content of 10 wt.%, suggesting that the addition of TNTs is beneficial for promoting the Cu dispersion and improving the Cu surface area. When the TNTs content increases to 15 wt.%, these two values decrease to 9.0% and 24.5 m2/g, respectively. This may be ascribed to that part of metallic Cu metal particles are covered by the excess TNTs, which is in agreement with the results of XRD and N2 adsorption/desorption. 3.2 Catalyst reduction behavior The reduction behavior of the calcined CZC, CZC/10TNTs and CZC/10P25 was investigated and H2-TPR profiles are presented in Fig. 3 . For these three samples, only one broad reduction peak is observed at temperature ranging from 150 to 600 °C, which is assigned to CuO and a part of metal oxides (ZnO and CeO2) reduction. To further obtain a better insight into their reduction process, the H2-TPR profiles of three samples are deconvoluted into three Gaussian peaks. The low-temperature peak is assigned to the reduction of surface-dispersed CuO, medium-temperature peak is related to the reduction of bulk CuO, and high-temperature peak is ascribed to the reduction of surface ZnO and CeO2 [40,44,45]. It can be found that all three reduction peaks of CZC/10TNTs and CZC/10P25 shift to lower temperature compared with CZC. Moreover, CZC/10TNTs exhibits the lowest reduction temperatures among all catalysts, suggesting that the introduction of TNTs into CZC significantly enhances the reducibility of catalysts. In addition, the relative surface-dispersed CuO concentration (C surface-dispersed) can be approximately calculated from the peak areas (A) of the two different CuO species, i.e., C surface-dispersed = A surface-dispersed/(A surface-dispersed + A bulk). The results are 53.9% for CZC, 60.8% for CZC/10TNTs and 57.6% for CZC/10P25. This implies that the surface-dispersed CuO concentration in CZC/10TNTs is higher than that in CZC and CZC/10P25, which is similar to that of BET surface area and Cu dispersion results. Considering the catalyst reduction temperature (350 °C) used in this study, all CuO species (surface-dispersed and bulk CuO) can be fully reduced to metallic Cu in all catalysts, in accordance with the result of XRD and previous research [40,44,46]. Therefore, the addition of TNTs into the CZC catalysts not only improves the CuO dispersion and surface-dispersed CuO concentration but also decreases the reduction temperature. 3.3 Catalyst surface basicity Fig. 4 depicts the CO2-TPD curves of the entire series of the reduced CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalysts before and after modification by TNTs or P25. All the investigated catalysts contain three typical desorption peaks (peaks α, β, and γ) resulting from desorption of CO2 from weak, medium and strong basic sites, respectively. For all reduced catalysts, peak α is associated with linear adsorptive form, peak β and γ can be attributed to bridge-bonded and horizontal adsorptive forms, respectively [29–31,47]. Linear adsorptive form shows single adsorptive site and exhibits weaker adsorption, but bridge-bonded and horizontal adsorptive forms show double adsorptive sites and present stronger adsorption [29–31]. It can also be seen from Fig. 5 that all three peaks shift to higher temperature with the incorporation of TNTs or P25, illustrating that support addition enhances the CO2 adsorption strength on the catalysts. Moreover, the maximum temperature of peak γ (595 °C) is obtained on the CZC/10TNTs catalyst, suggesting the highest strength of the strong basic sites in CZC/10TNTs. This may be ascribed to the excellent dispersion of active component after addition of TNTs. The number of different basic sites and their contributions are calculated by integration of each peak, and the quantitative data is listed in Table 2 . It can be found that all supported catalysts present more superior CO2 adsorption capacity than the support-free catalyst, revealing that the incorporation of TNTs or P25 into CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalysts provides more active sites for the adsorption of CO2 and enhances the inter-dispersion of mixed metal oxides [28]. Moreover, the variations in the number of basic sites γ and the contribution of basic sites γ to the total basic sites are different from those of the number of total basic sites. The order of the increasing number and proportion of basic sites γ is consistent with that of the increasing BET surface area, and the maximum values of 55.1 μmol/g and 18.4% are obtained over CZC/10TNTs. This may be ascribed to the fact that the increase in the BET surface area can improve the number of exposed strong basic sites. 3.4 Catalytic performance The influence of TNTs or P25 addition to the CuO-ZnO-CeO2 composites on the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation performance as a function of reaction temperature is presented in Fig. 5. For all the catalyst samples, CH3OH and CO are the only two carbon-containing products at the experimental conditions used in this work. In this study, 20–40 mesh catalyst was used for all catalytic tests and preliminary experiments indicated a negligible internal diffusion resistance. Thus, the mass transfer limitation is eliminated and the intrinsic catalytic activity is obtained. As seen in Fig. 5a, all catalysts show an increase in their respective CO2 conversion with the increase of reaction temperature in the whole reaction, suggesting that CO2 conversion could be kinetically enhanced with increasing the reaction temperature from 220 to 300 °C. Furthermore, the support-free catalyst (CZC) exhibits the lowest CO2 conversion among all catalysts, and the promotional effect of TNTs or P25 on the CO2 conversion is clearly found. For CZC/xTNTs (x = 0, 1, 5, 10 and 15) the CO2 conversion increases gradually when the TNTs addition increases from 0 to 10 wt.%. With further increasing the TNTs content to 15 wt.%, the CO2 conversion decreases, illustrating that the excess TNTs are not beneficial for CO2 activation. Moreover, the conversion of CZC/10P25 is 24.2% higher than that of un-modified catalyst (CZC) and 20.6% lower than that of CZC/10TNTs at a temperature of 260 °C, respectively. In addition, CZC/10TNTs shows the CO2 conversion of about 18% at 230 °C, which is lower than the CO2 equilibrium conversion (> 25%) calculated at the identifical reaction conditions from thermodynamic investigation [48,49]. This result indicates that CO2 hydrogenation to methanol reaction is working under kinetic regime. In Fig. 6 b, for each catalyst, the CH3OH selectivity always decreases with increasing the reaction temperature. CZC/10TNTs shows the highest CH3OH selectivity of 76.5% at 220 °C and then drops down to 33.5% at a temperature of 300 °C. This phenomenon could be explained by the fact that more competing side reactions easily take place at higher reaction temperature, especially rWGS reaction, which is thermodynamically favorable with ascending the reaction temperature [50]. As we all know, space time yield gives a direct benchmark to product productivity. According to the results of the CO2 conversion and CH3OH selectivity, the CH3OH STY as a function of reaction temperature over catalysts can also be got and the corresponding data is displayed in Fig. 5c. Unlike the conversion of CO2 and the selectivity of CH3OH, the STY of CH3OH of all examined catalysts follows a volcano-shaped trend with a maximum value at 260 °C. As shown in Fig. 5c, the addition of TNTs or P25 to CuO-ZnO-CeO2 can obviously enhance the CH3OH STY. The order of the CH3OH STY at a temperature of 260 °C is as follows: CZC/10TNTs (9.33 mmolCH3OH h−1·gcat −1) > CZC/5TNTs (7.56 mmolCH3OH h−1·gcat −1) > CZC/15TNTs (7.10 mmolCH3OH h−1·gcat −1) > CZC/10P25 (6.68 mmolCH3OH h−1·gcat −1) > CZC/1TNTs (5.94 mmolCH3OH h−1·gcat −1) > CZC (4.76 mmolCH3OH h−1·gcat −1). The TOF represents the number of CH3OH production on unit site of exposed copper atom per second (s−1), which exhibits the catalytic efficiency of single Cu atom on the catalyst surface. As depicted in Fig. 5d, all supported catalysts shows higher TOF CH3OH than the support-free catalyst, and CZC/10TNTs has the highest TOF CH3OH among all catalysts. At the same time, the variation of the TOF CH3OH is similar with that of the CH3OH STY with increasing the reaction temperature. According to the above results, the CZC/10TNTs catalyst presents the highest CO2 conversion, CH3OH selectivity, CH3OH STY and TOF CH3OH among all tested catalysts, and it thus exhibits the most excellent catalytic CO2 hydrogenation performance. In addition, it is worth stressing that the CH3OH STY and TOF CH3OH of all catalysts reach their maximum values at 260 °C. Hence, the optimal condition is at 260° in this study. According to the results of catalysts characterization and catalytic tests, a correlation between the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance has been established. As reported by previous researchers [51–55], the exposed copper surface area is an important parameter for Cu-based catalysts as it is closely related to the catalytic performance of catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6, in the measured temperature range (220–300 °C), a clear linear relationship between the CO2 conversion and SCu is established. We have fitted all the data points and obtained the minimum correlation coefficient R2 value of 0.8814, indicating that all data points present a perfect linear relationship. This result can be interpreted as follows: hydrogen atoms are generated by dissociative adsorption of H2 on the surface of Cu0 metal active sites, and then these desorbed H can hydrogenate the adsorbed carbon-containing species to form CO or CH3OH. Higher SCu denotes that more hydrogen atoms are formed on the Cu0 active species surface. Hence, higher CO2 conversion is obtained. Based on the above result and analysis, it can be found that the introduction of TiO2 is beneficial for promoting the Cu dispersion and improving the Cu surface area, and thus increases the CO2 convesion. In addition, the correlation between selectivity of CH3OH and the proportion of basic sites γ over various catalysts is also investigated. As seen in Fig. 7 , it should be mentioned that as the proportion of basic sites γ increases, the CH3OH selectivity presents a linearly increasing trend in the temperature range of 240–300 °C. The formaldehyde (H2CO) species adsorbed on the basic sites β and γ are the important intermediate phases, which can hydrogenate or dissociate to CH3OH or CO. Compared with the H2CO adsorbed on the moderate basic sites β, those adsorbed on strong basic sites γ prefer to be hydrogenated to CH3OH rather than dissociate to produce CO [51,56–58]. Hence, the CH3OH selectivity is correlated with the proportion of basic sites γ for the catalysts. In addition, the CH3OH selectivity has no obvious increase with increasing the proportion of basic sites γ at a reaction temperature of 220 °C, which may be attributed to that insufficient hydrogen atoms at lower temperature are provided for further hydrogenation of the H2CO intermediate species to CH3OH. Some researchers have reported that the methanol selectivity is also closely correlated to the CO2 conversion in CO2 hydrogenation systems [59,60]. To further obtain a better insight into the effect of the introduction of TiO2 on the methanol selectivity, the systematic comparison should be carried out at similar CO2 conversion for a given temperature. Herein, the relationship between methanol selectivity and proportion of basic sites γ over various catalysts is established, which indicates that strong basic sites have a certain effect on the selectivity of methanol. In addition, the further research on CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH need to be made in the future. In order to evalutate the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation performance of CZC/10TNTs, a comparision was done between CZC/10TNTs and other Cu-ZnO based catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The corresponding results are tabulated in Table 3 . It can be found that CZC/10TNTs shows a more superior catalytic performance than Cu/ZnO/ZrO2, TiO2/CuO-ZnO-Al2O3 and CuO-ZnO-ZrO2-Al2O3 in terms of CH3OH STY. Furthermore, CuO-ZnO-ZrO2-Al2O3/rGO presents a similar CH3OH STY to CZC/10TNTs. This can be explained by the fact that the addition of rGO support into CuO-ZnO-ZrO2-Al2O3 remarkably enhances the H2 and CO2 adsorption capacity and thus improve the catalytic activity. Compared to these results, our catalyst stsyem seems to be promising, even if it still needs to be optimized. The CO2 hydrogenation mechanism for CH3OH synthesis over various catalysts, especially for Cu-based catalysts, has been proposed by many researchers [56–65]. Based on our experimental results and literature reports, a possible bifunctional CO2 hydrogenation mechanism over the TNTs supported CZC catalysts is proposed and shown in Fig. 8 . In this scheme, H2 is dissociatively adsorbed into H* on the surface of the metallic Cu [18,28,56]. As mentioned above, TNTs incorporation enhances the CuO dispersion and reducibility. Thus, more H2 can be adsorbed onto these Cu active sites. Then, CO2 adsorption and activation take place over the metal oxide and/or support surface sites. It is noteworthy that the diameter of TNTs is much bigger than that of CO2 (0.33 nm), therefore, CO2 is also adsorbed and activated on both the inner and outer TNTs surfaces [40]. Subsequently, the adsorbed H* transfers to the metal oxide and/or support surface sites and combines with CO2* to form HCOO*, which then reacts with H* in succession to obtain H2COO* and H2CO* [59–62]. Finally, H2CO species can be hydrogenated to H3CO and CH3OH or dissociate to generate CO [63,64]. It should be mentioned that the H2CO* can be adsorbed on both the basic sites β and γ. And the ones adsorbed on the medium basic sites β easily dissociate to get CO, while the others adsorbed on the strong basic sites γ are prone to be hydrogenated into H3CO* and CH3OH [51,56–58]. Notably, there are a large number of Cu active phases and basic sites γ in CZC/10TNTs, which leads to its superior catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions The 1-dimensional TiO2 nanotubes with outer diameters of 60–80 nm and lengths of several hundred nanometers are perfectly formed by hydrothermal method. After loading of CuO-ZnO-CeO2, the morphology and structure of nanotubes are well remained and metal particles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of TNTs. It is clear that the addition of support has an obvious promoting effect on CuO-ZnO-CeO2 system, which not only promotes CuO reducibility and improves the metallic Cu dispersion and specific surface area, but also enhances CO2 adsorption and increases the proportion of basic sites γ. In catalytic tests, the CO2 conversion and CH3OH selectivity increase at first, reach their maximum values at a TNTs content of 10 wt.%, and then decrease with further increasing the TNTs content. It is found that CO2 conversion is positively correlated with the Cu specific surface area, and CH3OH selectivity is related to the proportion of basic sites γ. Moreover, a possible bifunctional mechanism is proposed for CH3OH formation from CO2 hydrogenation. Firstly, H2 is dissociatively adsorbed on the metallic Cu surface and CO2 is adsorbed on the metal oxide and/or support surface sites. Subsequently, the adsorbed H* transfers to the metal oxide and/or support surface sites and reacts with CO2* to form CH3OH. CZC/10TNTs has the excellent reducibility, high metallic Cu surface area, superior CO2 adsorption and large proportion of basic sites γ. It, therefore, gives excellent catalytic performance and exhibits a great potential as catalyst for methanol synthesis. coredata.dc:description: TiO2 nanotubes (TNTs) have been extensively applied in many fields owing to their excellent porous structure and surface properties. Herein, a series of CuO-ZnO-CeO2/TNTs catalysts are synthesized through a deposition-precipitation method. The effects of TNTs content and support morphology on the catalyst physicochemical properties and catalytic performance are investigated. The incorporation of TNTs support into CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalysts not only promotes CuO reducibility and improves the metallic Cu dispersion and specific surface area, but also enhances CO2 adsorption and increases the proportion of basic sites γ, thereby resulting in high CO2 conversion and CH3OH selectivity. It is also shown that CO2 conversion is positively correlated with the Cu specific surface area and that CH3OH selectivity is related to the proportion of basic sites γ. Due to the excellent reducibility, high metallic Cu surface area, superior CO2 adsorption and large proportion of basic sites γ, CuO-ZnO-CeO2/10 wt.% TNTs gives excellent catalytic performance and possesses a great potential as catalyst for methanol synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over TiO2 nanotubes-supported CuO-ZnO-CeO2 catalyst
